occurrences.line_text: Fond knight (sayd she) the thing that with this eye
Lo recreant (sayd he) the fruitlesse end
He made him open chalenge, and thus boldly sayd.
Fond Squire, full angry then sayd Paridell,
And sayd, Fond dame that deem'st of things diuine
Certes (sayd he) ye mote as now excuse
This other day (sayd he) a stranger knight
A stranger knight, sayd he, vnknowne by name,
That thus he sharply sayd; Now by my head,
Sayd then Sir Scudamour, Sir Saluage knight
Ah sad AEmylia (then sayd Amoret,)
True he it said, what euer man it sayd,
One of the worlds seuen wonders sayd to bee,
Whether old Proteus true or false had sayd,
For during Saturnes ancient raigne it's sayd,
Who was it then (sayd Artegall) that wrought?
Aread (sayd he) which way then did he make?
No sooner sayd, but streight he after sent
And sayd, Now sure this doubtfull causes right
Sith then (sayd he) ye both the dead deny,
Not so thou Squire, (he sayd) but thine I deeme
Now by my life (sayd he) and God to guide,
He sayd that he would all the earth vptake,
For why, he sayd they all vnequall were,
Therewith the Gyant much abashed sayd;
Which is (sayd he) more heauy then in weight,
Wroth wext he then, and sayd, that words were light,
Well then, sayd Artegall, let it be tride.
Now take the right likewise, sayd Artegale,
He long astonisht stood, ne ought he sayd,
That vnto him the horse belong'd, and sayd;
So hauing sayd, the younger did ensew;
Then Artegall thus to the younger sayd;
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
Then turning to the elder thus he sayd;
Your right is good (sayd he) and so I deeme,
How hight that Amazon (sayd Artegall?)
Her name was Clarin, and thus to her sayd;
Clarin (sayd she) thou seest yond Fayry Knight,
(Sayd he) nor obstinate disdainefull mind,
But sayd, that he was obstinate and sterne,
Till she againe thus sayd; Talus be bold,
Ah wellaway (sayd then the yron man,)
Sayd I not then (quoth shee) erwhile aright,
For she had vow'd, she sayd, not to forgo
Ye guilty eyes (sayd she) the which with guyle
Certes (sayd she) sith ye so well haue spide
And thus vpbrayding sayd; This token beare
Certes I wote not well (the Prince then sayd)
Thereto both his owne wylie wit, (she sayd)
Were not (sayd she) that it should let your pace
To which when she approched, thus she sayd;
(Sayd she) yet now I gin new life to feele,
Ay me (sayd she) and whether shall I goe?
And further sayd; Ah Sir, but mote ye please,
What is there else (sayd he) left of their rout?
Now turne againe (Sir Artegall then sayd)
Sayd Artegall; What foule disgrace is this,
For what soeuer good by any sayd,
Now happy man (sayd then Sir Calidore)
Sayd Artegall, I such a Beast did see,
Sayd Calidore, and to be ouerthrowne.
Sayd then that Squire: The Lady which doth owne
False traytor Knight, (sayd she) no Knight at all,
If I doe so, (sayd he) then liberty
With goodly patience, thus he to him sayd;
Sayd then Sir Calidore; Neither will I
Certes Sir knight (sayd she) full loth I were
Then speaking to the Ladie, thus he sayd:
T rue is, that whilome that good Poet sayd,
But he nought weighing what he sayd or did,
Ill seemes (sayd he) if he so valiaunt be,
Her chearing vp, thus gently to her sayd;
Yet was it sayd, there should to him a sonne
And soothly it was sayd by common fame,
And thus he to them sayd; Faire daughter Dame,
Aye me (sayd then Serena sighing sore)
But sith we need good counsell (sayd the swaine)
The best (sayd he) that I can you aduize,
Thus hauing sayd, his sickely patients
The knights beleeu'd, that all he sayd, was trew,
And sayd; Now sure ye well haue earn'd your meed,
Like as that other knight to him had sayd:
Fell flat to ground, ne word vnto him sayd,
And to the Prince thus sayd; See you Sir Knight,
Her tongue to her restord, then thus she sayd;
Certes (sayd then the Prince) the God is iust,
Here in this bottle (sayd the sory Mayd)
Ah nay Sir Knight (sayd she) it may not be,
For sleepe they sayd would make her battill better.
How much (sayd he) more happie is the state,
Sayd Calidore ; Now sure it yrketh mee,
Ah well away (sayd he then sighing sore)
For they themselues were euill groomes, they sayd,
My liefe (sayd she) ye know, that long ygo,
Most certaine markes, (sayd she) do me it teach,
She long so held, and softly weeping sayd;
Had made his caytiue thrall; againe he sayde,
Saying, that harlot she too lately knew,
Saying, Yet O thou dreaded Dame, I craue
The wicked witch, saying; In that faire face
Saying, he now had boulted all the floure,
So saying euery Nymph full narrowly she eyde.
Saying, Thou foolish knight, that weenst with words
Saying, but if she Mercie would him giue
Saying, Ah noble knight, what worthy meed
Saying it was to Knight vnseemely shame,
Saying, Sir knight, it would dishonour bee
Saying, Sir Knight, of pardon I you pray,
Saying; Deare Lady, deedes ought not be scand
Saying, that he had with vnmanly guile,
Saying and doing all that mote behoue;
That seemd the fountaine in that sea did sayle vpright.
That went at will, withouten carde or sayle,
Two dayes now in that sea he sayled has,
Now hight Palemon, and is saylers frend;
Were like two sayles, in which the hollow wynd
With his broad sayles, about him soared round:
Who swelling sayles in Caspian sea doth crosse,
About them flew, and fild their sayles with feare:
But strikes his sayles, and vereth his mainsheat,
The sayling Pine, the Cedar proud and tall,
And with them sayling thence, to th'Isle of Paros came.
Of euery blaste, and sayling alwaies on the port.
What to Aeneas fell; sith that men sayne
And great adue[n]tures found, that now were lo[n]g to sayne.
So scabby was, that would haue loathd all womankind.
Was ouergrowne with scurfe and filthy scald;
In straunge disguize, to slake his scalding smart;
Let Scaldis tell, and let tell Hania,
That hill they scale with all their powre and might,
To scale the skyes, and put Ioue from his right:
In th'other scale; but still it downe did slide,
So first the right he put into one scale;
To fill the other scale with so much wrong.
And ouer, all with brasen scales was armd,
Such noyse his rouzed scales did send vnto the knight.
And shoke his scales to battell readie drest;
Bright Scolopendraes, arm'd with siluer scales,
Her garments gay with scales of fish, that all did fill.
Whose scalp is bare, that bondage doth bewray,
His monstrous scalpe downe to his teeth it tore,
Vpon his crested scalpe so sore did smite,
An yron brest, and backe of scaly bras,
And scaly tayle was stretcht adowne his backe full low.
And glauncing from his scaly necke, did glyde
Which with a teeme of scaly Phocas bound
And saw the fieldes of faire Scamander strowne
Diuine Scamander, purpled yet with blood
It was no time to scan the prophecie,
Where they mote heare the matter throughly scand
Saying; Deare Lady, deedes ought not be scand
Vse scanted diet, and forbeare your fill,
That euer scap'd: for of a man they say
Ne let that wicked woman scape away;
And often semblaunce made to scape out of their hand.
And saw no meanes to scape, of shame affrayd,
That may not hope by flight to scape aliue,
Once, when he with Asterie did scape,
But who can scape, what his owne fate hath wrought?
That they were fayne to let him scape away,
The rest that scape his sword and death eschew,
But few returned, hauing scaped hard,
That cursed wight, from whom I scapt whyleare,
I onely scapt through great confusione
Could scarce recouered be out of her paine;
Which faintly fluttring, scarce his helmet raught,
So forth he fiercely prickt, that one him scarce could see.
Close vnderneath his shield, that scarce did show,
And almost blind through eld, that scarce her way could see.
A faire Pauilion, scarcely to be seene,
When her weake feete could scarcely her sustaine,
Staid not to answer, scarcely did refraine,
Yet scarcely once to breath would they relent,
Faire Amoret, that scarcely she could ryde;
That he which way to turne him scarcely wist:
Who scarcely yet from former feare exempted,
Thereat the Scarcrow wexed wondrous prowd,
Of his grim face, were from approaching scard;
And scared nations doest with horrour sterne astownd.
The way to her, and those two losels scared.
She with her scarfe did bind the wound fro[m] cold to keepe.
And finding in the way the scattred scarfe,
Her linnen stole to robe of scarlet red,
A goodly Lady clad in scarlot red,
That scarlot whore to keepen carefully;
But spoile her of her scarlot robe, and let her fly.
Bespred with costly scarlot of great name,
Her with a scarlot mantle couered,
Such cruell game my scarmoges disarmes:
For many scarres and many hoary heares,
Of Princesse worthy, scarse them bad arise.
Scarse could he once vphold his heauie hed,
His dronken corse he scarse vpholden can,
Ne scarse good morsell all his life did tast,
It carried, that I scarse in darkesome place
Scarse could he footing find in that fowle way,
His pined corse, him scarse to light could beare,
That vew of eye could scarse him ouertake,
Ne scarse his feet on ground were seene to tred;
Scarse had he said, when hard at hand they spy
And scarse them leasure gaue, her passing to behold.
Scarse do they spare to one or two or three,
That the hard rocks could scarse from teares refraine,
It lets not scarse this Prince to breath at all,
He falleth nigh to ground, and scarse recouereth flight.
That scarse he him vpheld from falling in a sound.
That from reuenge their willes they scarse asswag'd:
That scarse the Squire his hand could once vpreare,
That any bud thereof doth scarse remaine,
That his scarse diet somewhat was amended,
Scarse so conceiued in her iealous thought,
Could scarse vphold; yet soone she it requit.
And hidden wayes, that scarse an hound by smell
That whether man or monster one could scarse discerne.
Yet but a slender slip, that scarse did see
Ne scarse wyld beasts durst come, there was this wights abode.
Scarse yeelding her due food, or timely rest,
They both deformed, scarsely could be known.
That scarsely could he weeld his bootlesse single blade.
Scarsely had Phoebus in the glooming East
Ne scarsely who before: like as a Beare
And scarsely suffring her infestred wound,
That what of them became, themselues did scarsly weete.
Vnmanly murder, and vnthrifty scath,
To worke new woe and improuided scath,
Whose freedome shall thee turne to greatest scath.
Mote breede him scath vnwares: but all in vaine;
Tryde often to the scath of many deare,
To him, without regard of gaine, or scath,
Into a Tygre, and that Tygres scath
Are wont in Princes courts to worke great scath and hindrance.
Where he mote worke him scath and villeny.
Thenceforth more mischiefe and more scath he wrought
And vnderneath their feet, all scattered lay
Scattered on euery mountaine, as he went,
Whose carcases were scattered on the greene,
Poore Orphane in the wide world scattered,
And low behinde her backe were scattered:
But all the ground with sculs was scattered,
Like scattered Sheepe, whenas the Shepheards swaine
Out of the Troians scattered of-spring,
His weapons, which lay scattered all abrode,
By scattered shields was easie to be showen.
With filthy lockes about her scattered wide,
And all about her altar scattered lay
Her brothers bones she scattered all about;
But shiuered all about, and scattered in the wynd.
To saue themselues, and scattered were abrode:
A rauenous Wolfe amongst the scattered flockes.
And scattered all about, fell on the flowre.
In th'inner parts, and lastly scattering
Of neighbour Scots, and forrein Scatterlings,
Her scattred brood, soone as their Parent deare
Scattred with bushy thornes, and ragged breares,
And finding in the way the scattred scarfe,
That here and there like scattred sheepe they lay.
But scattred all about, and strow'd vpon the greene.
Like scattred chaffe, the which the wind away doth fan.
Ne ceassed not, till all their scattred crew
That they lay scattred ouer all the land,
His scattred people, ere they all were slaine,
Like scattred sheepe, to seeke for safetie,
Their thickest troups, & round about him scattreth wide.
So sure and swiftly, through his perfect scent,
Vpon the scepter, which she now did hold:
That with her soueraigne powre, and scepter shene
Which had seuen hundred yeares this scepter borne,
The first and eldest, which that scepter swayd,
Who mightily that scepter did sustayne,
And letteth her that ought the scepter weeld,
Holding a Scepter in her royall hand,
Of him, that did the kingly Scepter beare,
Their scepters stretcht from East to Westerne shore,
Ne thine be kingdomes, ne the scepters thine;
There were rent robes, and broken scepters plast,
Might scerne, that it was not his sweetest sweet,
As in her vertuous rules to schoole her knight,
To many a one, which came vnto her schoole,
To loue my selfe I learned had in schoole.
In sort as he him schooled priuily:
To haue her knight into her schoolehouse plaste,
The great schoolmistresse of all curtesy:
For by his mightie science he could take
And by her hellish science raisd streightway
Such wondrous science in mans wit to raine
But chiefly skill to ride, seemes a science
All artes, all science, all Philosophy,
And with sweet science mollifide their stubborne harts.
Or hellish feend raysd vp through diuelish science.
For by his mightie Science he had seene
By his deepe science, and hell-dreaded might,
Well seene in euerie science that mote bee,
Stout Scipio, and stubborne Hanniball,
Then them to haue my selfe, and be their seruile sclaue.
Sclaunder her guests doth staine:
And wickedly backbite: Her name men Sclaunder call.
Of euill words, and wicked sclaunders by him shed.
To her, that so false sclaunders at him threw.
Like sparkes of fire, which fall in sclender flex,
About her sclender wast, he tooke in hand,
Her selfe then tooke he by the sclender wast,
She stretched forth a long white sclender wand.
Who scornes thy ydle scoffe, and bids thee be defyde.
Whose scoffed words he taking halfe in scorne,
That turned all her pleasance to a scoffing game.
Scoffing at him, that did her iustly wite,
Of her vaine plaint, and to her scoffing sayd;
And scoffing, thus vnto his mother sayd,
She arm'd her tongue, and thought at him to scold;
Yet found no fault, but that the Hag did scold
And comming to her sonne, gan first to scold,
So much the more at him still did she scold,
Bright Scolopendraes, arm'd with siluer scales,
And cursed night, that reft from him so goodly scope.
So huge a scope at first him seemed best,
And graunt more scope to me to walke at large.
Which speaches she applying to the scope
And Eagles wings, for scope and speedinesse,
That ere they come vnto their aymed scope,
Does scorch not halfe so sore, nor damned ghoste
Consume his hart, and scorch his Idoles face,
That erst all entrers wont so cruelly to scorch.
Of scorched deaw, do not in th'aire more lightly flee.
And left their scorched path yet in the firmament.
Hurled his beame so scorching cruell hot,
And scorching Sunne does dry my secret vaines:
And scorching flames of fierce Orions hound,
And face all tand with scorching sunny ray,
This Nymph, quite tyr'd with heat of scorching ayre,
The scorching flame sore swinged all his face,
To saue his bodie from the scorching fire,
Did heale his wounds, and scorching heat alay,
To passe, for succour from the scorching ray,
And was yclad, for heat of scorching aire,
It now deuoures with flames and scorching heat,
Nor scorching heat, nor cold intemperate
Ne suffred she the Middayes scorching powre,
Others lay shaded from the scorching heat;
From scorching heat her daintie limbes to shade:
What time the dayes with scorching heat abound,
Or else some woodman shrowded there from scorching sunne.
And backe retire, all scorcht and pitifully brent.
Vpon his shield the like was also scor'd,
To weet why on your shield so goodly scord
Thence forth were brought to him aboue a score
My lambes doe euery yeare increase their score,
Till scornd of God and man a shamefull death he dide.
I euer scornd, and ioyd to stirre vp strife,
And though he scornd his idle vanitie,
And Paridell her scornd, and set at nought,
They quite forgot, and scornd all former law;
But scornd them all, that loue vnto her ment:
Seemd in their song to scorne the cruell sky.
Or who shall not great Nightes children scorne,
But all the Satyres scorne their woody kind,
All other powres and knighthood he did scorne.
horse is made the scorne
The scorne of knighthood and trew cheualrye,
Sonne (said he then) let be thy bitter scorne,
That made him scorne all creatures great and small,
And as in scorne of his spent stormy spight,
Wherewith her mother Art, as halfe in scorne
Scorne the faire offer of good will profest;
The worlds reproch, the cruell victors scorne,
Thereat Diana gan to smile, in scorne
To scorne the ioy, that Ioue is glad to seeke;
He comes not here, we scorne his foolish ioy,
But she with angry scorne him did withstond,
To keepe vs out, in scorne of his owne will,
Griefe, and despight, and gealosie, and scorne
Whose scoffed words he taking halfe in scorne,
But if through inward griefe or wilfull scorne
For his friends sake her offred fauours scorne,
And at one stroke cropt off her head with scorne,
Who full of scorne to be commaunded so,
And made the scorne of Knighthod this same day.
As that, albe all loue of men she scorne,
And trampled downe in dust his thoughts disdained scorne.
That is the greatest shame and foulest scorne,
But scorne of armes that hast with guilty hand
Tooke in foule scorne, that I such fault did find,
His meanesse much, & make her th'others riches scorne.
If I would beare behinde a burden of such scorne.
Did scorne the challenge of so base a thrall:
I giuen haue, liue in reproch and scorne;
Was Scorne, who hauing in his hand a whip,
He would him scorne, that to his gentle mynd
Disdaine and Scorne, I through the world should stray,
And is behinde me trodden downe of Scorne,
They heapt huge strokes, the scorned life to quell,
And scorned parts were mingled with the fine,)
To be so scorned of a base borne thrall,
He scorned in his ouerweening pryde;
Lo vnderneath her scornefull feete, was layne
Inflam'd with scornefull wrath and high disdaine,
For Guyons lookes, but scornefull eyglaunce at him shot.
Which when those knights beheld, with scornefull eye,
Or quite deuourd her beauties scornefull grace.
So drag'd him through the waues in scornefull state,
But it was scornefull Braggadocchio,
Which scornefull offer, Blandamour gan soone despize.
Which when that scornefull Squire of Dames did vew,
With proud disdaine did scornefull answere make;
Vnto his scornefull Lady, that for her had sent.
His scornefull taunts vnto his teeth againe,
To be the man, that with such scornefull pryde
Should issue forth, t'attach that scornefull lasse.
That downe he kept him with his scornefull sway,
Which not abiding, but more scornefully
But he on it lookt scornefully askew,
And sitting carelesse on the scorners stoole,
Who scornes thy ydle scoffe, and bids thee be defyde.
The gentle heart scornes base disparagement.
Where that discourteous Dame with scornfull pryde,
Scorning the let of so vnequall foe:
She scorning both their spights, does make wide way,
The hot-spurre youth so scorning to be crost,
As scorning his vnmanly cowardize:
Scorning her offers and conditions vaine;
Words sharpely wound, but greatest griefe of scorning growes.
Soone as they did the monstrous Scorpion vew,
And recompenst him with a better scorse:
Could not arise, the counterchaunge to scorse,
And from the country back to priuate farmes he scorsed.
So wedded th'one to Maglan king of Scots,
Of neighbour Scots, and forrein Scatterlings,
Of Scots and English both, that tyned on his strand.
She scould, and frownd with froward countenaunce,
Shame lowrd, Repentance sigh'd, Reproch did scould;
That made him scoule, and pout, and oft complaine
But to forray the land, or scoure the deepe.
Him often scourg'd, and forst his feete to fynd:
And therewith scourge the buxome aire so sore,
To be the plague and scourge of wretched men:
And out of court him scourged openly.
So sore him scourgeth, that the bloud downe followeth.
And scourging th'emptie ayre with his long traine,
Scourging and haling him more vehement;
And forth issuing with his scouts afore,
In three great riuers ran, and many countreis scowrd.
Who after her as hastily gan scowre,
Like puttocks clawes: with th'one of which she scracht
The which her sire had scrap't by hooke and crooke;
Yet scratch my sonne, or rend his tender hand?
Gan him to hale, and teare, and scratch, and bite;
Now scratching her, and her loose locks misusing;
And scratcht her face with ghastly dreriment,
And smot, and bit, and kickt, and scratcht, and rent,
And scratcht his face, and with his teeth did teare
With briers and bushes all to rent and scratcht;
And rent his haire and scratcht his face for paine.
He grind, hee bit, he scratcht, he venim threw,
There as they entred at the Scriene, they saw
The litle babe did loudly scrike and squall,
But laid them vp in his immortall scrine,
His scrip did hang, in which his needments he did bind.
Some made in books, some in long parchme[n]t scrolles,
And hauing scruzd out of his carrion corse
Into her cup she scruzd, with daintie breach
Into his wound the iuyce thereof did scruze,
As it had bene two shepheards curres, had scryde
Lay forth out of thine euerlasting scryne
That through his threesquare scuchin percing quite,
Saue to the noble knight Sir Scudamore,
All for she Scudamore will not denay.
Yet thou vile man, vile Scudamore art sound,
Ah gentlest knight aliue, (said Scudamore)
And Scudamore here dye with sorrowing.
Where late she left the pensife Scudamore,
findes Scudamour distrest:
And turning backe to Scudamour, thus sayd;
Whom whenas Scudamour saw past the fire,
She left Sir Scudamour in great distresse,
Twixt Scudamour and Blandamour:
For from the time that Scudamour her bought
To be Sir Scudamour, by that he bore
But Scudamour was shortly well aware
But Scudamour himselfe did soone vprayse,
False faitour Scudamour, that hast by slight
Ne be ye wroth Sir Scudamour therefore,
Vile hag (sayd Scudamour) why dost thou lye?
Which when as Scudamour did heare, his heart
So stood Sir Scudamour, when this he heard,
But Scudamour for passing great despight
Stird vp twixt Scudamour and Paridell,
Scudamour comming to Cares house,
The gentle Scudamour, whose hart whileare
Sir Scudamour there entring, much admired
There lay Sir Scudamour long while expecting,
Both Scudamour and Arthegall
Such was the wound that Scudamour did gride;
Which Scudamour perceiuing, forth issewed
Ah gentle Scudamour, vnto your grace
Whereto thus Scudamour, Small harme it were
When Scudamour heard mention of that speare,
Sayd then Sir Scudamour, Sir Saluage knight
Which when as Scudamour, who now abrayd,
But Scudamour now woxen inly glad,
But Scudamour whose hart twixt doubtfull feare
